thread.title: Maplin store closures could be announced next week

author: Isaac Ashe
title: Maplin store closures could be announced next week
text:
Maplin store closures could be announced next week No buyer has been found Share Click to play Tap to play The video will start in 8 Cancel Play now Get Business   Thank you for subscribing!   
The fate of some 2,500 workers hangs in the balance as Maplin has failed to find a buyer. 
The axe has already been swung on 129 jobs at the firm’s head offices in London and Rotherham, and thousands more are now expected to be made redundant. 
Stores look likely to begin shutting over the coming weeks. 
The retailer, owned by private equity firm Rutland Partners, appointed PwC to oversee an administration at the end of February after rescue attempts failed. Read More Mothercare, Moss Bros and CarpetRight: More big high street names struggling 
Maplin has 217 stores in the UK and, while PwC is attempting to find a buyer for the group, it is understood that no credible offer has materialised. 
It is thought that, if a white knight fails to emerge in the coming days, store closures could be announced as soon as next week. 
When Maplin went bust last month, it became the second retailer to collapse into administration in one day following the failure of Toys R Us, which is shutting all 100 of its UK stores. 
Maplin chief executive Graham Harris said at the time that the retailer had been struggling to mitigate the impact of the pound’s devaluation since the Brexit vote, along with a weak consumer environment and the withdrawal of credit insurance. Read More Could Poundstretcher be the next big name casualty on the high street in 2018? 
It comes in a dismal first quarter for the UK high street, with Carpetright also announcing on Wednesday the prospect of store closures, and Moss Bros and Mothercare also in the doldrums. 
Earlier this week New Look agreed a restructuring plan with creditors which will see it shut 60 stores, resulting in the loss of up to 980 jobs. 
A host of restaurant chains – including outlets run by celebrity chef Jamie Oliver, Prezzo and burger chain Byron – are also planning to shut hundreds of branches. Like us on Facebook
